answers.answer: You said in the post that you're diabetic and have polycystic ovaries, but in the title you mention that you had an ablation?  The diabetes would be significant in terms of safely carrying a pregnancy, but the ablation is really what would be the biggest concern.  Did you continue to have periods after your ablation?  If your basal endometrium was entirely destroyed, you're in a serious situation if you are pregnant.  If you are in doubt about having the termination, the person to discuss it with is a high-risk ob-gyn or a perinatologist (and they should have all your records when talking with you).  They are really the only one to tell you your odds of carrying a child safely.
yes sorry i did continue to have periods and i had the ablation 2 years ago

I had the same thing happen...I carried a healthy baby girl to term.  Check with your Doc before you choose termination.  After all I read, I too thought that was going to be my only alternative...I had really good Doc's who consulted with high risk Doc's and me and baby made it thru... Termination is final so don't rush the decision.
